page.lettertext:
It may please yo
r
H.
e post that brought yo
r
H. letters
of
e 19 and of the 21 of
e last, I dispatched hens,
two daies since. And I receaved this morning an ex-
tract from
Clarhaghe
of
e resoluc
o
n of
e
states of Utrecht
for his deliverance, wherof I have sent yo
r
H heereinclosed
the copie in French, whiche requireth him only to pay the
charges of the prison, and to take an oth for not molesting
any of the Burgeosie of
Utricht,
in respect of his impri-
sonment. This being done,
Count Meurs
notw
t
standing
sent an other schedule unto him, to subscribe and signe
before he could be released: wherein is contened, a con-
fession of more then he was ever charged w
t
all, and
very dishonorable conditions, w
ch
he hath rejected and
so continueth still in prison. Whereby it is evident
at
e Count, whatsoever he pretendeth to
e contrary, is his
greatest backfrinde. The conditions, by reason of the sod-
daine departure of a scheveling boate, by w
ch
I send
this letter, I have not
e leasure to gett translated, and
therfor send them in dutche. I am admitted by
the
states G
nr
all,
and by
e
Councell of state
to
M
r
Killigrewes
rowme, but as I signified in my former,
they can not well brooke
M
r
Gilpin
, and therfore stand
somwhat precisely in debating, before they fall to deciding
how they will receave him for an Interpreto
r
. W
t
Barnevelt,
to whome yo
r
H. letter did seeme very wel-
come, I have had suche c
o
ference, as my litle time heere
would affourd, but not to any purpose, to write any thing
of it. I was no sooner come to this towne but
Count
Maurice
, who lieth yet sicke of a burning fever, sent of his
gentleman to visit me: w
t
whome I was after, and did
yt is to be dowbted
that he goethe to
take possession of
somme frontyer
towne in
Frawnce
in this tyme of
Broyle.
Cambray
is to be feared
for that he was
a Ligueur.
her
Ma
ties
commendac
o
ns, w
t
other requisit complements.
He told me this day, that for certaine
e
D of Parma
mar
-cheth w
t
4 companies, as they write from
Andwerp,
towardes
Paris,
but as he doth conjecture, to remaine about
the frontiers. The conveing away to
Berghen
of
Madame Merodes
daughters, by
S
r
Thomas Morgan
and
S
r
Thomas Knolles
is muche misliked by the gentlemen heere,
w
ch
M
r
Killigrew and I endevo
r
where we come, to salve
as we may.
And thus I take mine humble leave of
yo
r
H. From
e Haghe. 3 Ja
n
88.
Yo
r
H. most humbly bounden Thomas Bodley.
